text: :This article is about the Japanese era name. For the software company, see Koei. was a of the Northern Court during the Nanboku-chō period after Ryakuō and before Jōwa. This period started in April 1342 and ended in October 1345.Nussbaum, Louis-Frédéric. (2005). "Kōei" in Japan encyclopedia, p. 541. The pretender in Kyoto was .Nussbaum, "Kōmyō Tennō," p. 555; Titsingh, Isaac. (1834). Annales des empereurs du japon, pp. 294-297. Kōmyō's Southern Court rival in Yoshino during this time-frame was .Nussbaum, "Go-Murakami Tennō," p. 257. ==Events of the Kōei era== * 1342 (Kōei 1, 2nd month): was removed from his position as Prime Minister (daijō daijin).Titsingh, p. 297. * 1342 (Kōei 1, 12th month): The mother of Ashikaga Takauji died. * 1343 (Kōei 2, 4th month): Nijō Yoshimoto, the author of Masukagami, was made Minister of the Right (udaijin). * 1344 (Kōei 3, 1st month): Shogun Takauji offered prayers at Iwashimizu Hachiman-gū. ==Southern Court nengō == * Kakitsu, 1441–1444 * Bun'an, 1444–1449 ==Related pages== * Muromachi period ==References== ==Other websites== * National Diet Library, "The Japanese Calendar" -- historical overview plus illustrative images from library's collection Kōei 1st 2nd 3rd 4th 1342 1343 1344 1345 Preceded by: Ryakuō Northern Court nengō: Kōei Succeeded by: Jōwa Category:Japanese eras Category:1340s establishments in Japan Category:1340s disestablishments in Japan
